A water tank has the form of a right circular cone of diameter \(3.66\,\text{m}\) and height of \(3.66\,\text{m}\) surmounted with a right circular cylinder of the same diameter and having a height of \(3.66\,\text{m}\). There is an orifice at the vertex of the cone whose area is \(0.0929\,\text{m}^2\). Initially the tank is full of water. Assume coefficient of discharge \(C = 0.60\). Evaluate the following after the orifice is opened:

1. The time to empty the cylindrical part of the tank.
2. The time to empty the conical part of the tank.
3. The total time to empty the tank.
solution:
Given:
Diameter = \(3.66\,\text{m}\)
Height = \(3.66\,\text{m}\)
Area of the orifice = \(0.0929\,\text{m}^2\)
\(C = 0.60\)

Required:
A. Time to empty the cylindrical part
B. Time to empty the conical part
C. Total time to empty the tank

Solution:

1. \(t_1 = 2A_s(\sqrt{h_1} - \sqrt{h_2})/(CA\sqrt{2g})\)
\(A_s = \pi(3.66)^2/4 = 10.52\,\text{m}^2\)
\(t_1 = 2(10.52)(\sqrt{7.32} - \sqrt{3.66})/(0.60(0.0929)\sqrt{2(9.81)}) = 67.53\,\text{s}\)

2. \(x/y = 1.83/3.66\), \(x = 0.5y\)
\(A_s = \pi x^2 = \pi(0.5y)^2 = 0.25\pi y^2\)
\(t_2 = \int_0^{3.66} A_s dy/(CA\sqrt{2gy})\)
\(t_2 = 0.25\pi/(0.60(0.0929)\sqrt{2(9.81)}) \int_0^{3.66} y^{3/2} dy\)
\(t_2 = 33.476\,\text{s}\)

3. \(t = t_1 + t_2\)
\(t = 67.53 + 33.476 = 101.006\,\text{s}\)

question:
Three pipes A, B and C are connected in parallel. If the combined discharge of the three pipes is equal to \(0.63\,\text{m}^3/\text{s}\) and assuming they have equal values of friction factor \(f\), compute the following using the tabulated data shown:

LineDiameter (m)Length (m)
10.15650
20.20550
30.10720


1. Compute the rate of flow of line 1 in L/s.
2. Compute the rate of flow of line 2 in L/s.
3. Compute the rate of flow of line 3 in L/s.
A column of mercury produces \(600\,\text{kPa}\). What is the equivalent height of water column?
solution:
Given:
\(p = 600\,\text{kPa}\)

Required:
A. Pressure head (\(p\))

Solution:

\(p = 600\,\text{kPa}\)
\(h_w = p/\gamma_w = 600/9.81\)
\(h_w = 61.162\,\text{m}\)

question: A mercury barometer at the base of the mountain reads \(700\,\text{mm}\). At the same time another barometer at the top reads \(650\,\text{mm}\). Assuming that the unit weight of air is constant at \(10\,\text{N}/\text{m}^3\), evaluate the approximate height of the mountain.
solution:
Given:
\(h_1 = 700\,\text{mm}\)
\(h_2 = 650\,\text{mm}\)
\(\gamma_{\text{air}} = 10\,\text{N}/\text{m}^3\)

Required:
Height of the mountain

Solution:

\(h_{\text{mountain}} = \Delta h_{\text{merc}}(\gamma_{\text{merc}}/\gamma_{\text{air}})\)
\(h_{\text{mountain}} = (0.7 - 0.65)((9810(13.6))/10)\)
\(h_{\text{mountain}} = 667\,\text{m}\)

question: If air had a uniform weight of \(12\,\text{N}/\text{m}^3\), what is the height of the atmosphere if the atmospheric pressure at sea level is \(101\,\text{kPa}\)?
solution:
Given:
\(\gamma_{\text{air}} = 12\,\text{N}/\text{m}^3\)
\(p = 101\,\text{kPa}\)

Required:
Height of the atmosphere

Solution:

\(h = p/\gamma\)
\(h = 101{,}000/12\)
\(h = 8416.666\,\text{m}\) or \(8417\,\text{m}\)

question: A hydraulic jack is used to support a load of \(90\,\text{kN}\). The hydraulic oil used has a specific gravity of \(0.81\). If the pressure below the piston is \(1.33\,\text{MPa}\), obtain the diameter of the piston in mm.
solution:
Given:
\(W = 90\,\text{kN}\)
\(\text{Sg} = 0.81\)
\(P = 1.33\,\text{MPa}\)

Required:
Diameter of the piston (mm)

Solution:

\(F = pA\)
\(pA = W\)
\((1.33)A = 90{,}000\)
\(A = 67669\,\text{mm}^2\)
\(A = \pi/4 D^2\)
\(67669 = \pi/4 D^2\)
\(D = 294\,\text{mm}\)

question: A cube, \(300\,\text{mm}\) on each side is to be held in equilibrium under water by attaching a lightweight foam buoy to it. The specific weights of the cube and the foam are \(20\,\text{kN}/\text{m}^3\) and \(0.81\,\text{kN}/\text{m}^3\), respectively. Evaluate the minimum volume of the foam in \(\text{m}^3\).
solution:
Given:
\(lwh = 300\,\text{mm} \times 300\,\text{mm} \times 300\,\text{mm}\)
\(\gamma_{\text{cube}} = 20\,\text{kN}/\text{m}^3\)
\(\gamma_{\text{foam}} = 0.81\,\text{kN}/\text{m}^3\)

Required:
Volume of the foam (\(\text{m}^3\))

Solution:

\(W = BF\)
\(W_{\text{foam}} + W_{\text{cube}} = BF_{\text{foam}} + BF_{\text{cube}}\)
\(0.81V_{\text{foam}} + 20(0.3)^3 = 9.81[V_{\text{foam}} + (0.3)^3]\)
\(V_{\text{foam}} = 0.0306\,\text{m}^3\)

question: A piece of wood \(0.6\,\text{m}\) square and \(1.8\,\text{m}\) high floats in water with \(0.5\,\text{m}\) outstanding. Evaluate the weight of wood in kN.
solution:
Given:
\(lw = 0.6\,\text{m} \times 0.6\,\text{m}\)
\(h = 1.8\,\text{m}\)

Required:
Weight of wood (kN)

Solution:

\(V_{\text{displaced}} = V_{\text{body}}(S_{\text{body}}/S_{\text{liquid}})\)
\((0.6)^2(1.3) = (0.6)^2(1.8)(S_{\text{body}}/1)\)
\(S_{\text{body}} = 0.722\)
\(W_{\text{wood}} = \gamma_{\text{wood}} V_{\text{wood}}\)
\(W_{\text{wood}} = (9.81 \times 0.722)(0.6)^2(1.8)\)
\(W_{\text{wood}} = 4.59\,\text{kN}\)

question: A block of wood (sg = 0.90) having a volume of \(0.1\,\text{m}^3\) is dropped into a tank containing a layer of liquid whose specific gravity is 0.6 on top of water. Obtain the volume of the block of wood submerged in the upper liquid in cubic meters.
solution:
Given:
\(\text{sg}_{\text{wood}} = 0.90\)
\(V_{\text{wood}} = 0.1\,\text{m}^3\)
\(\text{sg}_{\text{liquid}} = 0.6\)

Required:
Volume of the wood submerged in upper liquid (\(V_2\))

Solution:

\(V_1 + V_2 = 0.1\), \(V_1 = 0.1 - V_2\)
\(BF = W\)
\(BF_1 + BF_2 = W_{\text{wood}}\)
\(9.81V_1 + (9.81 \times 0.6)V_2 = (9.81 \times 0.9)0.1\)
\((0.1 - V_2) + 0.6V_2 = 0.09\)
\(V_2 = 0.025\,\text{m}^3\)

question: A capsized banca weighing \(12\,\text{kN}\) rest on seabed. It is desired to raise the banca by attaching an inflatable balloon to it. Evaluate the minimum volume of balloon to raise the banca. Use \(\text{sg}_{\text{sw}} = 1.03\) and neglect the weight of air and balloon.
solution:
Given:
\(W_{\text{banca}} = 12\,\text{kN}\)
\(\text{sg}_{\text{sw}} = 1.03\)

Required:
Volume of the balloon

Solution:

\(BF = W\)
\(\gamma_{\text{sw}} V_{\text{balloon}} = W\)
\((9.81 \times 1.03)V_{\text{balloon}} = 12\)
\(V_{\text{balloon}} = 1.19\,\text{m}^3\)

question: A ship having a displacement of \(30{,}000\) metric tons enters a harbour of fresh water. The ship captain recorded a draft of \(12.60\,\text{m}\) while the ship was still in seawater (specific gravity = 1.03). Obtain the draft, in meters, of the ship in fresh water if the horizontal section of the ship at the waterline is \(3000\,\text{m}^2\) in both instances.
solution:
Given:
\(\text{sg}_{\text{sw}} = 1.03\)
\(\text{sg}_{\text{fw}} = 1.0\)
\(d_{\text{sw}} = 12.6\,\text{m}\)
\(A_{\text{ship}} = 3000\,\text{m}^2\)

Required:
Draft in fresh water

Solution:

\(\Delta V_D = W/\gamma_{\text{fw}} - W/\gamma_{\text{sw}}\)
\(\Delta V_D = 30{,}000(1000)/1000 - 30{,}000(1000)/(1000(1.03))\)
\(\Delta V_D = 873.786\,\text{m}^3\)

Increase in draft: \(\Delta d = \Delta V_D/A_w = 873.786/3000 = 0.291\,\text{m}\)
\(d_{\text{fw}} = 12.60 + 0.291\)
\(d_{\text{fw}} = 12.891\,\text{m}\)

question: The triangular gate AB shown is hinged at its base B. The gate is \(4\,\text{m}\) wide perpendicular to its figure. Given: \(H = 6\,\text{m}\); \(z = 3\,\text{m}\); \(\theta = 45^\circ\). Find the horizontal force at the vertex A to open the gate, in kN.
solution:
Given:
\(H = 6\,\text{m}\)
\(z = 3\,\text{m}\)
\(\theta = 45^\circ\)

Required:
Horizontal force at A

Solution:

\(A = \frac{1}{2}(4)(6) = 12\,\text{m}^2\)
\(\bar{h} = 3 + 4\sin 45^\circ = 5.828\,\text{m}\)
\(F = \gamma_w \bar{h} A\)
\(F = 9.81(5.828)(12)\)
\(F = 686.1\,\text{kN}\)

\(e = I_g/(A\bar{y}) = ((4(6)^3)/36)/((5.828/\sin 45^\circ)(12))\)
\(e = 0.243\,\text{m}\)

question: The sector of a gate shown consist of a cylindrical surface of which AB is the trace. The length of the gate perpendicular to the paper is \(10\,\text{m}\), the radius \(R = 6\,\text{m}\), and the angle \(\theta = 60^\circ\). Evaluate the total horizontal force acting on the gate in kN.
solution:
Given:
\(\theta = 60^\circ\)
\(L = 10\,\text{m}\)
\(R = 6\,\text{m}\)

Required:
Horizontal force (\(F\))

Solution:

\(h = 6\sin 60^\circ = 5.196\,\text{m}\)
\(F = \gamma_w \bar{h} A = 9.81(5.196/2)(5.196 \times 10)\)
\(F = 1324.272\,\text{kN}\)

question: What is the pressure, in kPa, at the base of a container filled with \(1\,\text{m}\) deep water inside an elevator that is accelerating upwards at a rate of \(2\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2\)?
solution:
Given:
\(h = 1\,\text{m}\)
\(a = 2\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2\)

Required:
Pressure in kPa

Solution:

\(p = \gamma h(1 \pm a/g)\)
\(p = 9.81(1)(1 + 2/9.81)\)
\(p = 11.81\,\text{kPa}\)

question: A closed cylindrical tank \(1\,\text{m}\) in diameter and completely filled with water is rotated about its vertical axis at \(120\,\text{rpm}\). Compute the increase in pressure (kPa) at the rim of the tank.
solution:
Given:
\(d = 1\,\text{m}\)
\(\omega = 120\,\text{rpm}\)

Required:
Pressure at the rim of the tank

Solution:

\(\omega = 120\,\text{rpm} \times \pi/30 = 12.566\,\text{rad}/\text{s}\)
\(y_A = (12.566)^2(0.5)^2/(2(9.81))\)
\(y_A = 2.012\,\text{m}\)
\(P_A = \gamma_w y_A = 9.81(2.012)\)
\(P_A = 19.738\,\text{kPa}\)

question: An open cylindrical tank \(1.3\,\text{m}\) in diameter and \(2.1\,\text{m}\) high is \(2/3\) full of water. If the tank is rotated at \(87\,\text{rpm}\) about its vertical axis, obtain the volume of water spilled in liters.
solution:
Given:
\(D = 1.3\,\text{m}\)
\(H = 2.1\,\text{m}\)
\(\omega = 87\,\text{rpm}\)

Required:
Volume spilled

Solution:

\(\omega = 87 \times \pi/30 = 9.11\,\text{rad}/\text{s}\)
\(y = (\omega^2 r^2)/(2g) = ((9.11)^2(0.65)^2)/(2(9.81))\)
\(y = 1.787\,\text{m}\)

Drop in water level: \(\Delta h = y/2 - a = 0.8935 - 0.7 = 0.1935\,\text{m}\)
\(V_{\text{spilled}} = \pi/4 D^2 \Delta h = \pi/4(1.3)^2(0.1935)\)
\(V_{\text{spilled}} = 0.2562\,\text{m}^3 = 257\,\text{liters}\)

question: Evaluate the kinetic energy of a unit weight of water flowing at \(4\,\text{m}/\text{s}\).
solution:
Given:
\(v = 4\,\text{m}/\text{s}\)
\(g = 9.81\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2\)

Required:
Velocity head

Solution:

\(v^2/(2g) = 4^2/(2(9.81))\)
\(h = 0.815\,\text{m}\)

question: A fireman must put out a fire but is blocked by a firewall. To reach over the wall, he directed the water jet from the nozzle at an angle of \(30^\circ\) to the horizontal. Evaluate his maximum horizontal distance from the wall if the jet velocity exiting from the nozzle is \(20\,\text{m}/\text{s}\) and the wall is standing \(3\,\text{m}\) higher than the nozzle of the hose. Neglect friction in the jet and air resistance.
solution:
Given:
\(\theta = 30^\circ\)
\(v = 20\,\text{m}/\text{s}\)
\(y = 3\,\text{m}\)

Required:
Horizontal distance (\(x\))

Solution:

\(y = x\tan\theta - (gx^2)/(2v^2 \cos^2\theta)\)
\(3 = x\tan 30^\circ - (9.81x^2)/(2(20)^2 \cos^2 30^\circ)\)
\(x = 28.98\,\text{m}\)

question: Find the capacity (\(\text{m}^3/\text{min}\)) of a \(1\,\text{m}\) diameter pipe with a head loss of \(3\,\text{m}\) per km and frictional constant of \(0.025\).
solution:
Given:
\(D = 1\,\text{m}\)
\(HL = 3\,\text{m}\)
\(f = 0.025\)

Required:
Discharge (\(Q\))

Solution:

\(HL = (0.0826fLQ^2)/D^5\)
\(3 = (0.0826(0.025)(1000)Q^2)/1^5\)
\(Q = 1.205\,\text{m}^3/\text{s}\)
\(Q = 72.3\,\text{m}^3/\text{min}\)

question: Water flows at a rate of \(5\,\text{m}^3/\text{s}\) at a total head of \(10\,\text{m}\). Obtain the horsepower in the flow.
solution:
Given:
\(Q = 5\,\text{m}^3/\text{s}\)
\(H = 10\,\text{m}\)

Required:
Power

Solution:

\(P = Q\gamma H = 5(9810)(10)\)
\(P = 490{,}500\,\text{W}\)
\(P = 657.507\,\text{hp}\)

question: Water flows at a rate of \(0.18\,\text{m}^3/\text{s}\) in a straight \(200\,\text{mm}\) diameter horizontal pipe. Two mercury gages A and B \(150\,\text{m}\) apart shows a difference in reading of \(1.96\,\text{m}\). Evaluate the friction factor.
solution:
Given:
\(Q = 0.18\,\text{m}^3/\text{s}\)
\(D = 200\,\text{mm}\)
\(L = 150\,\text{m}\)

Required:
Friction factor (\(f\))

Solution:

\(H = 13.6(1.96) = 26.656\,\text{m}\) of water
\(HL = (0.0826fLQ^2)/D^5\)
\(26.656 = (0.0826f(150)(0.18)^2)/(0.2)^5\)
\(f = 0.021\)

question: A \(25\,\text{mm}\) diameter water jet flowing at \(8\,\text{m}/\text{s}\) hits a flat plate moving at \(3\,\text{m}/\text{s}\) in the same direction as the jet. Obtain the force exerted by the jet on the plane.
solution:
Given:
\(D = 25\,\text{mm}\)
\(v = 8\,\text{m}/\text{s}\) (jet)
\(v' = 3\,\text{m}/\text{s}\) (plate)

Required:
Force

Solution:

\(F = \rho A_j (v - v')^2(1 - \cos\theta)\)
\(F = 1000(\pi/4(0.025)^2)(8 - 3)^2(1 - \cos 0^\circ)\)
\(F = 12.275\,\text{N}\)

question: Water flows freely from the top of a \(20\,\text{m}\) high building. If \(0.5\,\text{m}^3\) of water flow in \(2\) seconds, compute the force as it hit the passers-by below.
solution:
Given:
\(h = 20\,\text{m}\)
\(V = 0.5\,\text{m}^3\)
\(t = 2\,\text{s}\)

Required:
Dynamic force

Solution:

\(F = \rho Q v\); \(v = \sqrt{2gh}\); \(Q = \text{Vol.}/\text{Time}\)
\(F = 1000(0.5/2)(\sqrt{2(9.81)(20)})\)
\(F = 4952.272\,\text{N}\)

question: Water flows on a \(5.4\,\text{m}\) wide open channel at a depth of \(1.20\,\text{m}\). The channel bed is on a slope of \(0.001\). Roughness coefficient is \(0.025\). Obtain the discharge through the channel in \(\text{m}^3/\text{s}\).

A cubic meter of water is subjected to a pressure increase of \(20\,\text{MPa}\). If the bulk modulus of elasticity of the water is \(2200\,\text{MPa}\), evaluate the change in volume in \(\text{m}^3\).
solution:
Given:
\(\Delta P = 20\,\text{MPa}\)
\(V = 1\,\text{m}^3\)

Required:
\(\Delta V = ?\) in \(\text{m}^3\)

Solution:

\(E_B = -\Delta P/(\Delta V/V)\)
\(\Delta V = (-\Delta P/E_B)V\)
\(\Delta V = -20/2200(1)\)
\(\Delta V = -0.009\,\text{m}^3\)

question: A manometer is attached to a conduit as shown. Compute the pressure at A in kPa given the following data: Specific gravity of Liquid B = 13.6, \(h = 125\,\text{mm}\), \(d = 375\,\text{mm}\).
solution:
Given:
\(\text{sg}_B = 13.6\)
\(h = 125\,\text{mm}\)
\(d = 375\,\text{mm}\)

Required:
\(P_A = ?\) in kPa

Solution:

\(P_B/\gamma + \text{sg}_B d - \text{sg}_A(h + d) = P_A/\gamma\)
\(0 + (13.6)(0.375) - (1)(0.125 + 0.375) = P_A/9.81\)
\(P_A = 45.126\,\text{kPa}\)

question: The velocity head of the flow at one section of a pipeline is \(5\,\text{m}\). Evaluate the velocity head, in meters, at the next section if the velocity of flow increases by one-half that of the previous section.

A right cylindrical container of diameter \(D\) (meter) and \(H\) (meter) high is filled with water \(z\) (meter) deep. A piece of timber, having a cross-sectional dimension \(b \times t\) (mm) and \(L\) (meter) long is freely allowed to submerge and float in a vertical position inside the container. The portion of the wood above the water surface is observed to be \(2/3\) the length of the timber. Given the following information, evaluate the specific weight of the timber, in \(\text{kN}/\text{m}^3\): \(D = 1.00\,\text{m}\), \(H = 5.00\,\text{m}\), \(z = 3.00\,\text{m}\), \(b = 250\,\text{mm}\), \(t = 250\,\text{mm}\), \(L = 3.00\,\text{m}\).
solution:
Given:
\(D = 1\,\text{m}\), \(H = 5\,\text{m}\), \(z = 3\,\text{m}\)
\(b = 250\,\text{mm}\), \(t = 250\,\text{mm}\), \(L = 3\,\text{m}\)

Required:
\(\gamma_t = ?\) in \(\text{kN}/\text{m}^3\)

Solution:

\(h_e = (2/3)L\), \(d = (1/3)L\)
\(d = (\gamma_b/\gamma_t)L = (\text{sg}_b/\text{sg}_L)L\)
\((1/3)L = (\gamma_{\text{timber}}/9.81)L\)
\(\gamma_t = 3.27\,\text{kN}/\text{m}^3\)

question:
A triangular plate of height \(h = 1.20\,\text{m}\) and base \(b = 2\,\text{m}\) is submerged vertically in water with its base at the liquid surface and parallel to it.

1. Evaluate the total force acting on one side of the plate, in kN.
2. Obtain the location of the force from the center of gravity of the plate, in mm.
3. Obtain the location of the force from the liquid surface, in mm.
solution:
Given:
\(h = 1.20\,\text{m}\)
\(b = 2\,\text{m}\)

Required:
1. \(F = ?\) in kN
2. \(e = ?\) in mm
3. \(y_{cp} = ?\) in mm

Solution:

1. \(F_H = \gamma \bar{h} A\)
\(F_H = 9.81(1/3(1.2))(1/2(2)(1.2))\)
\(F_H = 4.709\,\text{kN}\)

2. \(e = I_g/(A\bar{h}) = ((bh^3)/36)/(A\bar{h})\)
\(e = ((2(1.2)^3)/36)/((1/2)(2)(1.2)(0.4))\)
\(e = 0.2\,\text{m} \rightarrow e = 200\,\text{mm}\)

3. \(y = \bar{h} + e\)
\(y = 400 + 200\)
\(y = 600\,\text{mm}\)

question:
At a certain elevation above sea level, a mercury barometer reads \(700\,\text{mm}\).

1. What would be the corresponding reading of a water barometer in millimeters?
2. Evaluate the atmospheric pressure in kPa at that level.
3. What is the approximate elevation in meters above sea level, assuming normal atmospheric conditions? Neglect vapor pressure. Air weighs \(12\,\text{N}/\text{m}^3\).
solution:
Given:
\(P = 700\,\text{mmHg}\)
\(\gamma_{\text{air}} = 12\,\text{N}/\text{m}^3\)

Required:
1. \(P = ?\) in mm \(\text{H}_2\text{O}\)
2. \(P_{\text{atm}} = ?\) in kPa
3. \(h = ?\) in m

Solution:

1. Reading in mm of water = \(700(13.6)\)
\(P = 9520\,\text{mm}\,\text{H}_2\text{O}\)

2. \(P_{\text{atm}} = \gamma_{\text{mercury}} h_{\text{mercury}}\)
\(P_{\text{atm}} = 9.81(13.6)(0.7)\)
\(P_{\text{atm}} = 93.391\,\text{kPa}\)

3. \(h = P_{\text{atm}}/\gamma_{\text{air}}\)
\(h = 93391/12\)
\(h = 7782.583\,\text{m}\)

question:
In order to determine the volume and the specific gravity of a stone that weighs \(45\,\text{kg}\) in air, the engineer observed that when submerged in fresh water the stone weighs \(30\,\text{kg}\).

1. Evaluate the buoyant force acting on the stone, in N.
2. Obtain the volume of stone, in \(\text{m}^3\).
3. Evaluate the specific gravity of the stone.
solution:
Given:
\(W_A = 45\,\text{kg}\)
\(W_{\text{fw}} = 30\,\text{kg}\)

Required:
1. \(BF = ?\) in N
2. \(V = ?\) in \(\text{m}^3\)
3. \(\text{sg} = ?\)

Solution:

1. \(BF = W_A - W_{\text{fw}}\)
\(BF = 45 - 30 = 15\,\text{kg}\) \(= 15(9.81) = 147.15\,\text{N}\)

2. \(BF = \gamma V\)
\(15 = (1000)V\)
\(V = 0.015\,\text{m}^3\)

3. \(\text{sg} = \rho_{\text{stone}}/\rho_w\)
\(\rho = m/V = 45/0.015 = 3000\,\text{kg}/\text{m}^3\)
\(\text{sg} = 3000/1000 = 3\)

question:
The discharge pipeline of a water system consists of \(5500\,\text{m}\) of \(300\,\text{mm}\) pipe joined by \(3660\,\text{m}\) of \(450\,\text{mm}\) pipe that connects to the base of a huge water reservoir. The difference in elevation between the water surface in the reservoir and the center of the \(300\,\text{mm}\) pipe at the end of the line is \(45.7\,\text{m}\). Neglecting velocity head and other losses in head due to entrances and using coefficient of friction of \(0.02\) for both pipes,

1. Obtain the velocity of water in the bigger pipeline, in m/s.
2. Obtain the velocity of water in the smaller pipeline, in m/s.
3. Evaluate the rate of flow in the pipes, in \(\text{m}^3/\text{s}\).

Water flows through an almost rectangular channel \(3\,\text{m}\) wide at \(12\,\text{m}^3/\text{s}\). The depth of the channel gradually increases from \(1.0\,\text{m}\) to \(1.1\,\text{m}\) for a length of \(5\,\text{m}\).

1. What is the head loss in meters?
2. What is the slope of the energy gradient?
3. Obtain the value of the roughness coefficient.

A wooden buoy of specific gravity \(0.75\) floats in a liquid having a specific gravity of \(0.85\).

1. Evaluate the percentage of the volume of the buoy above the liquid surface to the total volume of the buoy.
2. If the volume above the liquid is \(0.045\,\text{m}^3\), estimate the weight of the buoy, in kN.
3. What vertical force, in kN, applied to the buoy to fully submerge it?

A single pipeline A joins pipelines 1, 2, and 3 at junction J and merges again at junction K to form a single pipeline B as shown in the figure. Pipeline 1, 2, and 3 are parallel to each other. The pressure heads at J and K are \(70\,\text{m}\) and \(46\,\text{m}\), respectively. Using Hazen Williams formula with \(C = 120\) for all pipes, obtain

1. Rate of flow in pipeline 1, in \(\text{m}^3/\text{s}\).
2. Rate of flow in pipeline 2, in \(\text{m}^3/\text{s}\).
3. Rate of flow in pipeline 3, in \(\text{m}^3/\text{s}\).

Given: \(D_1 = 300\,\text{mm}\), \(L_1 = 3000\,\text{m}\); \(D_2 = 200\,\text{mm}\), \(L_2 = 1300\,\text{m}\); \(D_3 = 250\,\text{mm}\), \(L_3 = 2500\,\text{m}\).

A \(1.50\,\text{m}\) diameter water main carrying \(2.15\,\text{m}^3/\text{s}\) branches at a point J to two pipelines, one \(300\,\text{m}\) long \(1.20\,\text{m}\) in diameter and the other \(1220\,\text{m}\) long and \(0.60\,\text{m}\) in diameter. Both pipes join at point K and continue as a single \(1.5\,\text{m}\) diameter pipe. The friction factors for the 1.50 m, 1.20 m, and 0.60 m pipes are \(0.02\), \(0.022\), and \(0.024\), respectively. Obtain:

1. The flow in the \(0.60\,\text{m}\) diameter pipeline in \(\text{m}^3/\text{s}\).
2. The flow in the \(1.20\,\text{m}\) diameter pipeline in \(\text{m}^3/\text{s}\).
3. The velocity of flow in the \(0.60\,\text{m}\) diameter pipeline.
